metadata.title: Immobilized silver on surface-modified ZnO nanoparticles: As an efficient catalyst for synthesis of propargylamines in water
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Immobilized silver on surface-modified ZnO nanoparticles: As an efficient catalyst for synthesis of propargylamines in water Farnaz Movahedi a ⁎ Hassan Masrouri a M.Z. Kassaee b a Department of Chemistry and Petrochemical Engineering, Standard Research Institute, P.O. Box 31745-139, Karaj, Iran Department of Chemistry and Petrochemical Engineering, Standard Research Institute P.O. Box 31745-139 Karaj Iran b Department of Chemistry, Tarbiat Modares University, P.O. Box 14155-4838, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry, Tarbiat Modares University P.O. Box 14155-4838 Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 912 7031230; fax: +98 26 32803880. Graphical abstract Silver nanoparticles were immobilized on ionic liquid modified zinc oxide nanoparticles leading to a ZnO-IL/Ag NPs catalyst, which exhibits high catalytic performance in the synthesis of propargylamines through one-pot three-component condensation reaction of aldehydes, amines, and alkynes in water. The as-prepared catalyst was characterized by ICP-AES, FT-IR, XRD, SEM, and TEM. The catalyst was easily recycled and reused at least five times without significant loss of its catalytic activity. Keywords Ag nanoparticles Heterogeneous catalysis Propargylamines Ionic liquid ZnO nanoparticles 1 Introduction The development of nano-sized metal particles has attracted considerable attention because of their promising applications in diverse fields [1–3]. They show great potential as versatile catalysts for green and sustainable organic synthesis owing to their large surface area and size-dependent properties different from bulk metals [4–6]. The control of their size, shape, dispersity, and in particular the combination of metal nanoparticles with a specific heterogeneous support, is essential to prevent aggregation and/or coalescence, resulting to enhanced activity and selectivity in a desired application [7–9]. Nanoparticles supported catalysts not only compete with their homogeneous counterparts but also, can be considered as ‘soluble’ analogues since they are readily dispersed and exhibit an intrinsically a high surface area, attribute that allow excellent accessibility of substrates to the surface bound active catalytic sites. Zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs) have their own importance due to their vast area of applications [10–14], especially in catalysis both as support and as active phase for hydrogenation or dehydrogenation reactions [15]. In addition, coverage of nanostructures by ionic liquids (ILs) is advised for construction of narrow size distribution nanoscale heterogeneous catalysts [16]. A kind of catalytic system in which the facile recovery and reuse of ionic liquids is achieved through covalent tethering to heterogeneous nanostructure supports [17,18]. This has led to a new possibility for developing environmentally friendly catalytic systems through stability in water and air, easy separation, high catalytic efficiency and reusability, resulting in vast applications for various organic reactions [19]. On the other hand, one-pot three-component catalytic couplings of aldehydes, amines and alkynes via C–H activation of the terminal alkynes have attracted a considerable interest in recent years [20]. The resultant propargylamines are major skeletons [21–23] and synthetically key intermediates [24–26] for preparation of many nitrogen containing biological active compounds, such as β-lactams, oxotremorine analogues, conformational restricted peptides, and therapeutic drugs [27,28]. Three-component synthesis of propargylamines has been reported using various transition metal catalytic systems such as Ag (І) salts [29], Au (ІІІ) salen complexes [30], Cu (І) salts [31], Cu/Ru bimetallic system [32], heteropolyacid-supported silver (Ag-HPA) [33], hydroxyapatite-supported copper (Cu-HAP) [34], AgY zeolite [35] as well as Ag-, Au- and Cu-nanoparticles [36–39]. Although these types of catalysts impose their own advantages and disadvantages to the reaction, the considerable drawback is that most of them proceed in toxic solvents and harsh conditions. Consequently, attempts to achieve more efficient and environmentally friendly methods for chemical synthesis of propargylamines still remains a big challenge and continues to be the focus of intense research. Herein, we report a new catalytic system based on Ag NPs immobilized on ZnO NPs modified with ionic liquid groups and its application as a novel and efficient catalyst for the A3-coupling reaction of aldehydes, amines and alkynes to produce propargylamines in water. We anticipated that Ag and ZnO NPs as heterogeneous sources, along with the ILs as the homogeneous matrix, would create a catalyst with efficiency beyond the customary limit. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and instruments The reagents and solvents used in this work were obtained from Fluka or Merck and used without further purification. Nanostructures were characterized using a Holland Philips Xpert X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) diffractometer (Co K, radiation, λ =0.178897nm), at a scanning speed of 2°/min from 10° to 80° (2θ). The particle size and morphology were investigated by a transition electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010 on an accelerating voltage of 200kV) and scanning electron microscope (SEM, Holland Philips XL30 microscope with an accelerating voltage of 25kV). FT-IR measurements were performed using KBr disc on a Thermo IR-100 infrared spectrometer (Nicolet). Elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed using a Heraeus CHN–O-Rapid analyzer. A radial view Varian Vista-Pro simultaneous ICP-OES (Springvale, Australia) coupled to a V-groove nebulizer and equipped with a charge coupled device (CCD) was applied for determination of the silver ions. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were measured at 500.1, and 125.7Hz, respectively, on a Bruker DRX 500-Avance FT-NMR instrument with CDCl3 as the solvent. 2.2 Synthesis of 1-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl)-3-methylimidazolium chloride [tmim][Cl] ionic liquid 1-Methylimidazole (2.0g, 25.0mmol) and (3-chloropropyl) trimethoxysilane (4.9g, 25.0mmol) were dissolved in toluene (20mL) and refluxed for three days. Then two phases formed, with 1-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl)-3-methylimidazolium chloride [tmim][Cl] as a viscous oil at the bottom and the solvent on the top. They were separated and the viscous oil was washed with toluene (5×10mL). After drying the oil under vacuum at 60°C for one day, ionic liquid (3.5g, 12.75mmol, 51% yield) was obtained with a honey-like consistency at room temperature [40]. 2.3 Surface modification of ZnO NPs with [tmim][Cl] ionic liquid ZnO NPs were synthesized through a solid-state reaction method including Zn(OAc)2·2H2O and sodium hydroxide in the ratio of 1:4 [41]. The obtained ZnO NPs (1.2g) were sonicated for 1h before being treated with [tmim][Cl] (0.277g, 1mmol) in anhydrous toluene under reflux condition overnight. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and the modified ZnO-IL(Cl) was washed with EtOH several times to remove the impurities and dried under vacuum. In order to increase the basic characteristic of the ionic liquid anchored on the surface of ZnO NPs, an anion-exchange processing was carried out using the modified ZnO-IL(Cl) (1.0g) and KOH (0.06g, 1mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20mL) for 2 days at room temperature. Finally, the modified ZnO-IL(OH) was obtained after centrifuging (4000rpm) and washing with H2O several times. According to elemental analysis, the loading capacity of ZnO NPs was determined to be 0.54 mmolg−1 of basic ionic liquid. 2.4 Immobilization of silver NPs on ionic liquid-modified ZnO NPs To a stirred solution of the modified ZnO-IL (1.0g) in deionized water (20mL) in 100mL round bottom flask was added a solution of AgNO3 (0.1g, 0.59mmol) in 20mL water, at room temperature. After 10min, N2H4·H2O (0.1g, 2.0mmol) was added in one portion as the reducing agent. The agitation continued for 12h. The resulting powder was centrifuged (6000rpm, 5min) and washed with deionized water and EtOH, then dried under vacuum at 60°C overnight to give the corresponding ZnO-IL/Ag NPs as a catalyst. 2.5 General procedure for the synthesis of propargylamines Catalyst (10mol%) was added to a mixture of aldehyde (1mmol), amine (1.1mmol) and phenylacetylene (1.2mmol) in water (3mL) at reflux conditions, and the mixture was stirred for appropriate periods. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. Consequently, the mixture was centrifuged (4000rpm, 5min) till the catalyst was settled down and the solvent containing the crude product was decanted out. The centrifugate was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2×5mL). The organic phase concentrated under reduced pressure to afford the crude product, which after chromatography on silica gel (100–200 mesh) using hexane:ethyl acetate, 90:10, gave the corresponding propargylamines. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of ZnO-IL/Ag NPs Following our recent reports on the catalytic potentials of ZnO NPs [41,42], surface of the prepared ZnO NPs were modified by treatment with the as synthesized 1-(3-trimethoxy silylpropyl)-3-methylimidazolium chloride [tmim][Cl] ionic liquid in refluxing toluene to be engaged as a heterogeneous nanostructure support. At the next stage, the modified ZnO-IL(Cl) were treated with potassium hydroxide in CH2Cl2 at room temperature, in order to increase the basic catalytic characteristic of the ILs anchored on the surface of ZnO NPs. Then AgNO3 and hydrazine monohydrate were added into the stirred solution of the modified ZnO-IL(OH) in deionized water, simultaneously. Ag NPs were produced while embedded into ionic liquid networks anchored on the surface of ZnO NPs (Scheme 1 ), in which was used as a heterogeneous catalyst in propargylamines synthesis. The Ag content was evaluated to be 0.31mmolg−1 by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. Also, the loading capacity of ZnO NPs was determined to be 0.54mmolg−1 of the basic ILs via the elemental analysis. Successful surface modification of the ZnO NPs with ionic liquid was evidenced by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectral analysis (Fig. 1 ). In contrast to the naked ZnO NPs, the modified ZnO-IL(OH) showed the characteristic peaks of imidazolium ring at 1570cm−1 and 1029cm−1, along with hydroxyl at 3417cm−1. The X-ray diffraction pattern of ZnO-IL/Ag NPs is shown in Fig. 2 . Three additional diffraction peaks appeared beside those attributed to the pure ZnO NPs. The XRD patterns of the ZnO NPs could be indexed to the hexagonal wurtzite structure (space group: P63mc; a =3.249Å, c =5.206Å, JCPDS card no. 36-1451), while the three additional peaks at 2θ =44.57°, 51.90° and 76.45° are assigned respectively to the diffraction line planes (111), (200) and (220), corresponding to the face-centre-cubic (fcc) of Ag NPs, in accordance with the JCPDS 04-0783. No evidence for any impurity was detected. Based on this study, the average particle size has been estimated 30nm for ZnO NPs and 7nm for Ag NPs by using Debye–Scherrer equation, D h,k,l =kλ/β cos θ, where k is a constant (generally considered as 0.89), λ is the wavelength of Co Ka (1.78897Å), β is the corrected diffraction line full-width at half-maximum (FWHM), and θ is Bragg's angle [43]. The morphology and grain size of the ZnO-IL/Ag NPs were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 3 ). Evidently, the corresponding diffraction pattern (Fig. 3c) can be indexed to the hexagonal wurtzite phase of ZnO in the size range of 25–35nm confirming the results extracted from the XRD pattern. Also, it is clear that Ag NPs are distributed on the surface of ZnO NPs. The average size of Ag NPs is estimated to be 6–10nm, in accordance with the XRD results. 3.2 Evaluation of the catalytic activity of ZnO-IL/Ag NPs through the synthesis of propargylamines We investigated the catalytic activity of ZnO-IL/Ag NPs as a heterogeneous catalyst in one-pot synthesis of propargylamines through three-component reaction of aldehydes, secondary amines and alkynes (Scheme 2 ). In an effort to develop an optimal catalytic system, various reaction parameters were probed for the condensation reaction of benzaldehyde, piperidine, and phenylacetylene as a model reaction. Various catalysts including bulk- and nano-ZnO, Ag NPs, and ZnO-IL/Ag NPs were evaluated for this model reaction, and the results are summarized in Table 1 . The reaction did not proceed in the absence of the catalyst neither in solvent-free conditions nor in water (Table 1, entries 1 and 2). Among the used catalysts, ZnO-IL/Ag NPs rendered the highest yield. Indeed, ZnO nanoparticles as well as Ag NPs would catalyze the reaction per se, with 61% and 78% yield, respectively. Yet, their combination in the form of ZnO-IL/Ag NPs boosts the yield to 92%. To appraise the effects of media, we carried out the condensation of benzaldehyde, piperidine and phenylacetylene in various organic solvents by using ZnO-IL/Ag NPs (20mg per 1mmol of reactants) as the catalyst (Table 1, entries 7–11 and 13). It should be noted that ZnO-IL/Ag NPs showed good catalytic activity in a variety of organic solvents such as acetonitrile and ethanol, where over than 80% conversion was obtained. Nevertheless, the reaction in water is very clean and this is the solvent of choice, environmentally appreciable. To investigate the effect of the catalyst concentration, systematic studies are carried out in the presence of different amounts of the catalyst (10, 20, 50mg) in water, affording propargylamines with 78%, 92%, and 92% isolated yields, respectively. Thus, the best yield is found in the presence of just 20mg ZnO-IL/Ag NPs, and the use of higher amounts of catalyst (50mg) does not improve the result to an appreciable extent (Table 1, entry 14). To evaluate the scope and the generality of the ZnO-IL/Ag catalyst, a variety of aliphatic and aromatic aldehydes as well as various secondary amines and alkynes was examined for preparation of the corresponding propargylamines (Table 2 ). Aliphatic aldehydes, such as isobutyraldehyde and n-butyraldehyde afforded better yields than most of the aromatic ones. Among the aromatic aldehydes, those possessing halide groups such as 4-chlorobenzaldehyde produced propargylamines in better yields than the aldehydes with electron-donating group like 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (Table 2, entries 2 and 4). Also, aldehydes with electron-withdrawing group such as 4-nitrobenzaldehyde did not produce any result. Among the amines, piperidine, pyrrolidine, and morpholine gave excellent yields of the propargylamines, whereas dibutylamine formed the corresponding product in moderate yield. When alkylacetylenes were used in place of phenylacetylene (Table 2, entries 23–26), the corresponding propargylamines were isolated in excellent yields. All products were characterized on the basis of their spectroscopic data such as FT-IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectra. A plausible mechanism for the formation of the product would be as follows: the immobilized Ag NPs on the surface of ZnO NPs insert in terminal alkyne to form the Ag acetylide intermediate through the activation of C–H bond. On the other hand, formation of the iminium ions from aldehydes and secondary amines could be accelerated in the presence of Lewis acid and base sites of catalyst core, Zn2+ and O2−, respectively. Condensation of Ag acetylide intermediate with iminium ion produced in situ, gives the corresponding propargylamine. The recyclability and reusability of the catalyst was investigated for the model A3-coupling reaction of benzaldehyde, piperidine and phenylacetylene in water. After each run, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation (4000rpm, 5min), washed with isopropanol and dried in an oven, then reused as such for subsequent experiment under similar reaction conditions. The results showed that the catalyst (either 20mg or the lower amounts for example 10mg) could be effectively used for at least five consecutive cycles without much appreciable loss in its catalytic activity (Table 3 ). The Ag content in the fresh catalyst and for the used catalyst, after 5 runs, was determined to be 0.31 and 0.28mmolg−1 by ICP, respectively. Such an excellent reusability and high stability of the catalyst could be attributed to the strong embedding of Ag NPs on the surface of the modified ZnO NPs. Indeed, the ionic liquid networks anchored on the surface of the heterogeneous nanoscale support, contribute significantly to the direct immobilization of the Ag NPs. A comparison for the efficiency of the catalytic activity of ZnO-IL/Ag NPs with several pervious methods is presented in Table 4 . The results show that this method is superior to some of the earlier methods in terms of yields and reaction times. Valuable capability of the catalyst is indicated by producing a wide range of propargylamines. The procedure would be in accordance with environmental norms because water is proposed as a green solvent for the reaction in which the catalyst could be recovered easily by centrifuging and decantation. 4 Conclusion The Ag NPs were embedded successfully in the ZnO-IL nanohybrid matrix. The as prepared ZnO-IL/Ag nanoparticles was applied as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the three-component coupling reactions of aldehydes, amines and alkynes in water to achieve propargylamines. This method offers several advantages including high yields, short reaction times, use of water as a green solvent, a simple work-up procedure, ease of separation and recyclability of the catalyst, as well as the ability to tolerate a wide variety of substitutions in the reagents. coredata.dc:description: Silver nanoparticles were immobilized on ionic liquid modified zinc oxide nanoparticles leading to a ZnO-IL/Ag NPs catalyst, which exhibits high catalytic performance in the synthesis of propargylamines through one-pot three-component condensation reaction of aldehydes, amines, and alkynes in water. The as-prepared catalyst was characterized by ICP-AES, FT-IR, XRD, SEM, and TEM. The catalyst was easily recycled and reused at least five times without significant loss of its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilized silver on surface-modified ZnO nanoparticles: As an efficient catalyst for synthesis of propargylamines in water
